title: Northern Lights as they were captured in all their glory across Northern Ireland - Belfast Live
text: From Belfast to Ballymoney and Carrickfergus to Ballynure, your pictures of the aurora borealis were spectacular Skygazers across Northern Ireland were promised a a 'decent chance' of seeing the spectacular Northern Lights on Thursday night - and nature didn't disappoint. From Belfast to Ballymoney and Carrickfergus to Ballynure, your pictures of the aurora borealis were breath-taking. Hues of green, blue, pink and purple danced across the sky during the eye-catching phenomenon, which is caused by solar activity that can cause charged particles in solar winds to smash into molecules in the Earth's atmosphere sparking the colourful displays. READ MORE: Satellites orbiting earth may help predict Lough Neagh blue-green algae blooms Intense auroras, which do occur occasionally, can be seen higher in the sky with a more distinct arc. But they are also best seen in darkness, away from light pollution and in skies clear of clouds. The Met Office says the lights can extend from 50 miles to as high as 400 miles above the Earth's surface. Almost anyone armed with a smartphone or digital camera can take a picture of auroras in the skies. Experts advise checking the best spots to capture them and whether there will be cloud cover.
